title: There are a lot of 'execution reversed' errors
body:
Hi, Excuse me, I am using blockscout to synchronize the eth mainnet explorer, I have 3 rpc nodes composed of erigon, they are basically running normally, but because the browser sends out a lot of queries per second for the token balance under the specified block number ( called hundreds of times per second).

My AWS EC2 is i4i.4xlarge, 16-core 128G, and has 7T Nvme storage.

So there are a lot of 'execution reversed' errors, is there any way I can improve this situation? I've made --rpc.gascap a lot bigger. My startup script is as follows.



```
./build/bin/erigon --datadir=/erigon/etharchive --chain=mainnet --port=30303 --http.port=8545 --authrpc.port=8551 --torrent.port=42069 --private.api.addr=127.0.0.1:9090 --http --ws --http.api=eth,erigon,web3,net,debug,trace,txpool --http.corsdomain=* --http.addr=0.0.0.0 --http.vhosts=* -rpc.batch.limit=5000 --rpc.returndata.limit=10000000 --trace.maxtraces=5000 --db.pagesize=32kb --snapshots=false --rpc.gascap=800000000
```

I'll just jump in here with an idea that is totally unrelated to Erigon and the RPC, but may work for you.

We had a similar problem and explored using the Multi-call smart contract which is deployed on a lot of different chains.

The idea is that you can make a single RPC call to the Multi-call contract, and in the call, send a list of addresses. The smart contract calls the balance function on the list of addresses and returns the results in a single JSON response.

Not only is it faster, but it only hits the RPC once for many addresses. This might alleviate the problem.

Here's a link to a library that uses the smart contract: https://github.com/joshstevens19/ethereum-multicall.

I've not tested it myself, but if you do, and it works, perhaps you can report back to this issue and perhaps close the issue.
Execution reverted is a bug with smart contract not erigon
